gravity_system: Roof Trusses, Loadbearing Walls, Continuous Footings
other_materials: Plywood, Rigid Insulation, Asphalt Shingles, Vinyl Siding, Brick/Stone Veneer
key_elements: Window Wells, Guard Rails, Weeping Tiles, Anchor Bolts, Sill Plates
overall_building_description: The Brophy Residence project involves a living room addition to an existing residential structure, requiring detailed integration of new and existing construction elements. The foundation system utilizes 9-inch thick concrete walls with a compressive strength of 25 MPa, supported by 18x6 inch concrete footings rated at 20 MPa. The foundation plan specifies the use of 15M rebar dowels, epoxied into existing foundations with a minimum embedment of 6 inches, ensuring structural continuity and load transfer. The foundation walls are designed to accommodate soil bearing capacities of 75 kPa or greater, with weeping tiles installed around footings to manage subsurface water, connected to a sump pit for effective drainage. The main floor plan features engineered roof trusses spaced at 24 inches on center, providing the primary roof support. These trusses are braced according to manufacturer specifications, ensuring lateral stability and load distribution. The exterior walls are constructed with 2x6 studs at 16 inches on center, insulated with R-20 batt insulation, and clad with a combination of 3 1/2 inch brick veneer and vinyl siding. The wall assembly includes a 6 mil poly vapor barrier and 7/16 inch OSB sheathing, providing thermal and moisture protection. The building's thermal performance is enhanced by R-60 insulation in ceilings with attic space and R-31 in ceilings without attic space, meeting Zone 1 requirements. The addition's glazing is limited to a 5% window-to-wall ratio, complying with OBC Table 9.10.15.4, ensuring energy efficiency and thermal comfort. The structural design incorporates LVL beams and W8x18 steel beams, providing support for floor joists and accommodating point loads. The lintel schedule specifies various configurations, including (2) 2x6 and (2) 2x8 lintels with king studs, ensuring adequate support for openings. The project adheres to the Ontario Building Code, with specific references to sections 9.8 for stair and guard rail design, and 9.6 for forced entry requirements. The construction notes emphasize the importance of verifying window and door dimensions with manufacturers, ensuring compliance with design specifications. The assembly sequences detail the installation of sill plates, secured with 3/8 inch anchor screws and sill gaskets, maintaining airtightness and structural integrity. The project requires careful coordination between trades, particularly in areas where new construction interfaces with existing structures, such as the removal and replacement of exterior brick and the installation of new pocket doors. The construction process must ensure that all vapor barriers are caulked and sealed at penetrations, maintaining the building envelope's integrity. The project also includes provisions for interconnected smoke alarm systems and carbon dioxide detectors, enhancing occupant safety. The detailed wall section illustrates the integration of various materials, including stone veneer, rigid insulation, and drywall, with specific attention to air/vapor barrier continuity and drainage management. The project requires adherence to strict fabrication and installation procedures, ensuring compliance with design criteria and performance requirements.
